Award.AwardTitle: Novel Single-Ion Conductors for Lithium-Ion Batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Wang, Qing
Proposal Number: 1235761
Institution: Pennsylvania State Univ University Park
Title: Novel Single-Ion Conductors for Lithium-Ion Batteries

In order to give a completely new direction in the development of high-performance electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries, this project examines single-ion conducting (SIC) electrolytes, a unique alternative to traditional lithium-ion battery electrolytes. Expected lithium-ion-transference number of unity can potentially eliminate electrolyte polarization losses in the cell that develops in a binary salt system, resulting in an increase in power capacity. The improvements are significant for applications where a high discharge rate is desired, such as electric vehicles.

This project examines the properties of the SICs with systematic structural variations by utilizing a comprehensive suite of characterization techniques along with electrochemical measurements to gain fundamental insight into the how the structure characteristics influence the film morphology, Li+ conduction, mechanical and thermal stability, electrochemical properties, and mechanisms of ion dissociation and transport that are desperately needed for this field to advance. The battery performance will be examined to establish full pictures of the structure-property-performance correlations. In addition, the influence of the SIC membranes on the formation, composition and morphology of the solid-electrolyte interface layer and their impacts on the cell performance will be examined.

The project, if successful as planned, will open a completely new direction in the development of high-performance electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries. Moreover, it will shed light on the fundamental understanding of ion transport and polymer electrolytes which are relevant for a range of advanced technologies such as actuators, alternative battery membranes, and fuel cells. The project will train scientists and engineers capable of working in the interdisciplinary field of energy storage. Through the collaboration with Seoul National University, the graduate students will gain valuable experience in the international research and education. Particular attention will be given to recruiting women and under-represented minority undergraduate research assistants through the Penn State Minority Undergraduate Research Experience, and Women in Science and Engineering Research programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lithium-ion batteries have been the technology of choice as rechargeable energy storage devices for portable electronics and electric vehicles because of their high energy density, flexible and lightweight design, and longer lifespan than comparable battery technologies. This work involves the design, synthesis and characterization of novel high-performance single ion conductor (SIC) membranes to break the current barriers in lithium-ion batteries based on conventional binary salt conductors. A lithium-ion transference number of unity can theoretically eliminate electrolyte polarization losses in the cell that develops in a binary salt system, resulting in an increase in maximum power. The improvements are significant for applications where a high discharge rate is desired, such as electric vehicles.

The polyaromatic and organic-inorganic SICs with systematically varied chemical structures and compositions have been designed and prepared. The electrochemical properties including Li+ transference number, cyclability, electrochemical stability, interfacial resistance of the prepared SICs have been systematically investigated using cyclic and linear voltammetry and impedance spectroscopy. The performance of the SIC based batteries, including the capacity, coulombic efficiency, rate performance, and cycle stability, has been examined. The hybrid membranes exhibit several advantages related to battery cell performance such as high electrochemical stability towards lithium metal and high lithium transference number. The flammability of the hybrid electrolytes has been investigated. The project has demonstrated new materials concepts for SICs, provided improved fundamental understanding of the mechanisms of Li-ion dissociation and transport, and established the chemical structure-electrochemical properties-battery performance correlations in the SICs.

The interdisciplinary project has provided exceptional opportunities for training of graduate and undergraduate students in a variety of techniques and fields: polymers, energy materials and engineering, structural and dielectric characterization, electrochemistry, battery fabrication, evaluation of battery performance, and in-depth understanding of structure-property-performance. Students engaged in the project are well-prepared to undertake new scientific and engineering challenges, especially in the interdisciplinary area of energy storage. Additionally, this project has fostered the participation of graduate students in an international experience through the collaborative international research efforts with National Seoul University. The undergraduate students from the Minority Undergraduate Research Experience (MURE) and Women in Science and Engineering Research (WISER) have been involved in the project. The PI has also attended several open houses and outreach events to promote participation of minority students and high school kids in science learning and career. The PI has delivered invited lectures on this project in the national meetings and various universities and companies such as Arkema.
